chapter.subject: Physics
chapter.chapter_name: Upthrust in fluids and Archimedes principle and floatation

questions.question_text: What is the upward force exerted by a fluid on a body submerged in it called?

options.label: A
options.text: Gravitational force

options.label: B
options.text: Viscous force

options.label: C
options.text: Upthrust or Buoyant force

options.label: D
options.text: Normal reaction

questions.question_text: Which of the following symbols is commonly used to denote buoyant force?

options.label: A
options.text: W

options.label: B
options.text: F_b

options.label: C
options.text: P

options.label: D
options.text: V

questions.question_text: A student states: 'Buoyancy is the downward force a liquid exerts on a body.' What is wrong with this statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Buoyancy is a property of solids, not liquids.

options.label: B
options.text: Buoyancy is the upward force, not downward.

options.label: C
options.text: Buoyancy only acts on gases, not liquids.

options.label: D
options.text: The statement is correct; buoyancy is a downward force.

questions.question_text: While pushing an empty can into water, one feels an upward force. This force is an example of:

options.label: A
options.text: Magnetic force

options.label: B
options.text: Frictional force

options.label: C
options.text: Upthrust

options.label: D
options.text: Tension

questions.question_text: How does the property of buoyancy in liquids compare to that in gases?

options.label: A
options.text: Only liquids have buoyancy; gases do not.

options.label: B
options.text: Both liquids and gases have buoyancy, but its effect is usually negligible in gases.

options.label: C
options.text: Gases have stronger buoyancy than liquids.

options.label: D
options.text: Buoyancy in gases acts downwards, opposite to liquids.

questions.question_text: Why do we not feel the buoyant force of air in daily life, but a hydrogen balloon rises?

options.label: A
options.text: Air has no buoyant force.

options.label: B
options.text: The upthrust due to air on our body is negligible compared to our weight, but for a hydrogen balloon, upthrust exceeds weight.

options.label: C
options.text: Our bodies are immune to buoyant forces.

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen cancels gravity.

questions.key_concept: Relative magnitude of upthrust and weight

questions.question_text: What are the two main forces acting on a body immersed in a fluid?

options.label: A
options.text: Magnetic and Electric

options.label: B
options.text: Weight (downwards) and Upthrust (upwards)

options.label: C
options.text: Friction and Tension

options.label: D
options.text: Gravity and Thrust

questions.question_text: A body floats when the weight (W) and the maximum upthrust (F_b,max) are related as:

options.label: A
options.text: W > F_b,max

options.label: B
options.text: W = F_b,max or W < F_b,max

options.label: C
options.text: W < F_b,max always

options.label: D
options.text: W is unrelated to F_b,max

questions.question_text: A common mistake is to think a body sinks only if its weight is greater than the upthrust when it is *partially* immersed. What is the correct condition for sinking?

options.label: A
options.text: Sinking occurs if weight > upthrust when the body is *completely* immersed.

options.label: B
options.text: Sinking occurs if weight > upthrust at any immersion level.

options.label: C
options.text: Sinking occurs if the body's density is less than air.

options.label: D
options.text: Sinking is independent of weight and upthrust.

questions.key_concept: Condition for sinking based on maximum upthrust

questions.question_text: An iron nail sinks in water but a ship floats. This is primarily because:

options.label: A
options.text: The nail is smaller.

options.label: B
options.text: The ship's average density is less than water's density.

options.label: C
options.text: Water exerts less upthrust on the ship.

options.label: D
options.text: The nail is made of a magnetic material.

questions.question_text: Compare the states of a body when (i) p = p_l and (ii) p < p_l, where p is body density and p_l is liquid density.

options.label: A
options.text: In both cases, the body sinks.

options.label: B
options.text: In (i) it floats completely immersed; in (ii) it floats partially immersed.

options.label: C
options.text: In (i) it floats partially immersed; in (ii) it sinks.

options.label: D
options.text: In both cases, the body floats with the same fraction submerged.

questions.question_text: A body of density greater than a liquid sinks. What provides the net downward force causing this acceleration?

options.label: A
options.text: The viscous force of the liquid.

options.label: B
options.text: The net force (W - F_b,max) acting downwards.

options.label: C
options.text: The absence of upthrust.

options.label: D
options.text: Magnetic attraction to the bottom.

questions.key_concept: Net force on a sinking body

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic property of upthrust?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases with the submerged volume.

options.label: B
options.text: It acts downwards at the body's centre.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases with the density of the fluid.

options.label: D
options.text: It acts upwards at the centre of buoyancy.

questions.question_text: The point where the buoyant force is considered to act is called the:

options.label: A
options.text: Centre of mass

options.label: B
options.text: Centre of buoyancy

options.label: C
options.text: Geometric centre

options.label: D
options.text: Pivot point

questions.question_text: A student thinks: 'Upthrust depends only on the weight of the body, not the fluid.' Why is this incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Upthrust is independent of the body's weight.

options.label: B
options.text: Upthrust depends on the density of the fluid and the submerged volume, not the body's weight.

options.label: C
options.text: Upthrust depends on the body's shape but not the fluid.

options.label: D
options.text: The student's statement is correct.

questions.question_text: Identical corks are placed in water and glycerine. The cork in glycerine has a smaller volume immersed because:

options.label: A
options.text: Glycerine is less dense.

options.label: B
options.text: Glycerine is denser, exerting greater upthrust for the same volume.

options.label: C
options.text: Water has higher viscosity.

options.label: D
options.text: Cork absorbs glycerine.

questions.question_text: Compare the centre of buoyancy (B) and centre of gravity (G) for a uniform body (i) completely immersed and (ii) floating with part submerged.

options.label: A
options.text: In (i) B coincides with G; in (ii) B is below G.

options.label: B
options.text: In (i) B is above G; in (ii) B coincides with G.

options.label: C
options.text: In both cases, B is above G.

options.label: D
options.text: In both cases, B is below G.

questions.question_text: In a vacuum, a bunch of feathers and a pebble of equal mass fall together. In air, the pebble falls faster. Why?

options.label: A
options.text: Air resistance is greater on the pebble.

options.label: B
options.text: Upthrust due to air is greater on the feathers (larger volume) reducing its net downward acceleration.

options.label: C
options.text: The pebble is more aerodynamic.

options.label: D
options.text: Gravity acts more strongly on the pebble.

questions.question_text: What is the fundamental cause of upthrust on a body immersed in a fluid?

options.label: A
options.text: Difference in fluid pressure between the top and bottom surfaces of the body.

options.label: B
options.text: The body's magnetic field interacting with the fluid.

options.label: C
options.text: The fluid's temperature gradient.

options.label: D
options.text: The body's own motion.

questions.key_concept: Pressure difference as cause of upthrust

questions.question_text: In a fluid, pressure increases with:

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in depth

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in depth

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in surface area

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease in density

questions.question_text: A student reasons: 'A thin sheet (lamina) sinks because water exerts no upthrust on it.' Is this correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because pressure is equal on both sides, resulting in negligible net force.

options.label: B
options.text: No, a lamina experiences greater upthrust because it's thin.

options.label: C
options.text: No, a lamina floats due to surface tension.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, because laminae are always denser than water.

questions.question_text: Consider a block immersed in a liquid. The net upward thrust is calculated as (P2 - P1)A. What does 'A' represent?

options.label: A
options.text: Acceleration due to gravity

options.label: B
options.text: Area of cross-section of the block

options.label: C
options.text: Altitude

options.label: D
options.text: The amplitude of vibration

questions.key_concept: Formula for upthrust from pressure difference

questions.question_text: Compare the horizontal thrusts on the vertical sides of an immersed block.

options.label: A
options.text: They are unequal and cause rotation.

options.label: B
options.text: They are equal and opposite, so they balance each other.

options.label: C
options.text: They add up to give a net horizontal force.

options.label: D
options.text: They are zero because pressure only acts vertically.

questions.question_text: Why does the pressure on the lower face of an immersed block (P2) exceed the pressure on the upper face (P1)?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the lower face is at a greater depth, and pressure increases with depth.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the lower face has a larger area.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the fluid above the block pushes it down.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the weight of the block itself.

concepts.concept_name: Upthrust equals Weight of Displaced Liquid (Archimedes' Principle)

questions.question_text: Archimedes' principle states that the upthrust on a body is equal to:

options.label: A
options.text: The weight of the body

options.label: B
options.text: The volume of the body

options.label: C
options.text: The weight of the fluid displaced by the body

options.label: D
options.text: The density of the fluid

questions.question_text: The mathematical expression for upthrust (F_b) in terms of volume displaced (V), fluid density (ρ), and gravity (g) is:

options.label: A
options.text: F_b = V / (ρg)

options.label: B
options.text: F_b = V ρ g

options.label: C
options.text: F_b = ρ g / V

options.label: D
options.text: F_b = V ρ / g

questions.question_text: A common error is to think Archimedes' principle applies only to liquids. What is the correct scope?

options.label: A
options.text: It applies only to water.

options.label: B
options.text: It applies to liquids only.

options.label: C
options.text: It applies to fluids (liquids and gases).

options.label: D
options.text: It applies only to solids immersed in gases.

questions.key_concept: Archimedes' principle applies to all fluids

questions.question_text: In the eureka can experiment, if a solid weighs 300 gf in air and 200 gf in water, what is the weight of water displaced?

options.label: A
options.text: 500 gf

options.label: B
options.text: 100 gf

options.label: C
options.text: 200 gf

options.label: D
options.text: 300 gf

questions.key_concept: Loss in weight equals weight of fluid displaced

questions.question_text: Compare the upthrust on a body when it is (i) partially immersed and (ii) completely immersed.

options.label: A
options.text: Upthrust is zero in both cases.

options.label: B
options.text: Upthrust is greater when completely immersed (maximum).

options.label: C
options.text: Upthrust is greater when partially immersed.

options.label: D
options.text: Upthrust is the same in both cases.

questions.question_text: Why does a bucket of water feel lighter when lifted from inside a well (immersed) compared to when it is out?

options.label: A
options.text: Because its mass decreases in water.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the upthrust of water supports part of its weight, reducing the apparent weight.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the rope becomes elastic in water.

options.label: D
options.text: Because water lubricates the hands.

questions.key_concept: Apparent weight reduction due to upthrust

questions.question_text: What is Relative Density (R.D.)?

options.label: A
options.text: Ratio of density of substance to density of water at 4°C

options.label: B
options.text: Ratio of mass to volume

options.label: C
options.text: Density of water divided by density of substance

options.label: D
options.text: Weight of substance in air

questions.question_text: What is the unit of Relative Density?

options.label: A
options.text: kg/m³

options.label: B
options.text: g/cm³

options.label: C
options.text: Newton

options.label: D
options.text: It has no unit (dimensionless).

questions.question_text: A student calculates R.D. as 'Density of substance / Density of water at 0°C'. Why is this incorrect for standard R.D.?

options.label: A
options.text: Water density is maximum at 4°C, not 0°C. Standard R.D. uses water at 4°C.

options.label: B
options.text: Water density is minimum at 4°C.

options.label: C
options.text: R.D. should use density of air.

options.label: D
options.text: The formula is correct for any temperature.

questions.question_text: If the density of copper is 8.9 g/cm³, what is its Relative Density?
questions.key_concept: R.D. numerically equals density in CGS units

questions.question_text: Compare Density and Relative Density.

options.label: A
options.text: Both have SI unit kg/m³.

options.label: B
options.text: Density has units, R.D. is a ratio with no units.

options.label: C
options.text: R.D. is always greater than density.

options.label: D
options.text: Density is a vector, R.D. is scalar.

questions.question_text: Why is the density of water at 4°C chosen as the standard for Relative Density?

options.label: A
options.text: Because water is most abundant at 4°C.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the density of water is maximum at 4°C, providing a fixed reference point.

options.label: C
options.text: Because water freezes at 4°C.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's an arbitrary choice.

concepts.concept_name: Determination of R.D. of a Solid using Archimedes' Principle

questions.question_text: The formula to find R.D. of a solid (denser than water) using Archimedes' principle is:

options.label: A
options.text: R.D. = (Weight in air) / (Loss in weight in water)

options.label: B
options.text: R.D. = (Loss in weight) / (Weight in air)

options.label: C
options.text: R.D. = (Weight in water) / (Weight in air)

options.label: D
options.text: R.D. = (Weight in air) * (Weight in water)

questions.key_concept: Formula for R.D. of a solid

questions.question_text: In the experiment, if a solid is soluble in water, which liquid is used instead?

options.label: A
options.text: A liquid of known R.D. in which the solid is insoluble.

options.label: B
options.text: Any liquid denser than water.

options.label: C
options.text: Only mercury can be used.

options.label: D
options.text: The solid cannot be used at all.

questions.question_text: A student uses the formula R.D. = (Weight in air) / (Weight in water). What is the error?

options.label: A
options.text: It should be weight in air divided by loss in weight, not weight in water.

options.label: B
options.text: It should be weight in water divided by weight in air.

options.label: C
options.text: The formula is correct.

options.label: D
options.text: It should multiply the two weights.

questions.question_text: A solid weighs 50 gf in air and 44 gf in water. What is its R.D.?
Compare the procedures for finding R.D. of a solid denser than water and a solid soluble in water.

options.label: A
options.text: Both use water for immersion.

options.label: B
options.text: For soluble solid, a liquid of known R.D. is used, and the formula is adjusted by multiplying with R.D. of that liquid.

options.label: C
options.text: The procedure is identical; solubility does not matter.

options.label: D
options.text: For soluble solid, weight in air is not measured.

questions.question_text: Why must the solid not touch the sides or bottom of the beaker during the R.D. experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent heat transfer.

options.label: B
options.text: To avoid an additional upward reaction force from the beaker which would reduce the apparent weight incorrectly.

options.label: C
options.text: To make the setup look neat.

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent the solid from dissolving faster.

concepts.concept_name: Determination of R.D. of a Liquid using Archimedes' Principle

questions.question_text: To find R.D. of a liquid, a solid body is weighed in air, in the liquid, and in water. The formula is:

options.label: A
options.text: R.D. = (Loss in weight in liquid) / (Loss in weight in water)

options.label: B
options.text: R.D. = (Weight in liquid) / (Weight in water)

options.label: C
options.text: R.D. = (Weight in air) / (Weight in liquid)

options.label: D
options.text: R.D. = (Weight in water) / (Weight in air)

questions.key_concept: Formula for R.D. of a liquid

questions.question_text: What property must the solid body used in this experiment have?

options.label: A
options.text: It must be lighter than both liquids.

options.label: B
options.text: It must be heavier than both the liquid and water, and insoluble in them.

options.label: C
options.text: It must float in the liquid.

options.label: D
options.text: It must be magnetic.

questions.question_text: A student calculates R.D. of liquid as (Weight in air - Weight in liquid). What is missing?

options.label: A
options.text: It must be divided by (Weight in air - Weight in water).

options.label: B
options.text: It must be multiplied by density of water.

options.label: C
options.text: Nothing is missing; the formula is correct.

options.label: D
options.text: It must be added to the weight in water.

questions.question_text: A body weighs W1 gf in air, W2 gf in a liquid, and W3 gf in water. What is the expression for R.D. of the liquid?

options.label: D
options.text: W2 / W3

questions.key_concept: Application of R.D. formula for liquid

questions.question_text: Compare the purpose of weighing the solid in water versus in the unknown liquid in this experiment.

options.label: A
options.text: Weighing in water gives the volume of the solid; weighing in liquid gives the upthrust due to that liquid.

options.label: B
options.text: Both are done to find the density of the solid.

options.label: C
options.text: Weighing in water is optional.

options.label: D
options.text: Weighing in liquid gives the weight of the liquid.

questions.key_concept: Role of water and liquid measurements

questions.question_text: Why is it necessary to wash and dry the solid after weighing it in the liquid before weighing it in water?

options.label: A
options.text: To prevent contamination of water with the liquid, which would change water's density and affect the loss in weight measurement.

options.label: B
options.text: To make the solid lighter.

options.label: C
options.text: To cool down the solid.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not necessary.

questions.question_text: The principle of floatation states:

options.label: A
options.text: A floating body displaces its own weight of the fluid.

options.label: B
options.text: A floating body displaces its own volume of the fluid.

options.label: C
options.text: A floating body experiences zero gravity.

options.label: D
options.text: A floating body has density greater than the fluid.

questions.question_text: For a floating body, the apparent weight is:

options.label: A
options.text: Equal to its true weight

options.label: B
options.text: Greater than its true weight

options.label: C
options.text: Less than its true weight

options.label: D
options.text: Zero

questions.key_concept: Apparent weight of a floating body

questions.question_text: A student believes a floating body must be completely immersed. What is the actual condition?

options.label: A
options.text: A body floats if its weight equals the upthrust due to the submerged part; it can be partially or completely immersed.

options.label: B
options.text: It must be completely immersed to float.

options.label: C
options.text: It must have less than half its volume immersed.

options.label: D
options.text: It must have no part immersed.

questions.question_text: A wooden block floats on water. The forces acting on it are:

options.label: A
options.text: Weight (down) and Upthrust (up), which are equal.

options.label: B
options.text: Weight (down) and a sideways force.

options.label: C
options.text: Only weight acts.

options.label: D
options.text: Weight (up) and Upthrust (down).

questions.question_text: Compare the net force on a body that sinks versus one that floats.

options.label: A
options.text: Sinking body: net downward force; Floating body: net force zero.

options.label: B
options.text: Both have net upward force.

options.label: C
options.text: Sinking body: net force zero; Floating body: net upward force.

options.label: D
options.text: Both have net downward force.

questions.key_concept: Net force in sinking vs floating

questions.question_text: Why does a floating body experience zero apparent weight?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the upthrust exactly balances its weight, so no net force is felt.

options.label: B
options.text: Because gravity ceases to act on it.

options.label: C
options.text: Because its mass becomes zero in water.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is in a state of free fall.

concepts.concept_name: Relation: Submerged Volume, Density of Body and Liquid

questions.question_text: For a body of density ρ_s floating in a liquid of density ρ_l, the fraction of volume submerged (v/V) is given by:

options.label: A
options.text: v/V = ρ_s / ρ_l

options.label: B
options.text: v/V = ρ_l / ρ_s

options.label: C
options.text: v/V = (ρ_s - ρ_l) / ρ_l

options.label: D
options.text: v/V = constant

questions.question_text: If a body floats with its whole volume inside liquid, the relation between densities is:

options.label: A
options.text: ρ_s > ρ_l

options.label: B
options.text: ρ_s = ρ_l

options.label: C
options.text: ρ_s < ρ_l

options.label: D
options.text: ρ_s = 2 ρ_l

questions.key_concept: Condition for complete immersion while floating

questions.question_text: A common error is to think the submerged volume depends on the mass of the body only. What does it actually depend on?

options.label: A
options.text: It depends on the ratio of densities (ρ_s/ρ_l), not just mass.

options.label: B
options.text: It depends only on the body's mass.

options.label: C
options.text: It depends only on the liquid's density.

options.label: D
options.text: It is always half the total volume.

questions.question_text: A cork of density 0.5 g/cm³ floats on water (density 1 g/cm³). What fraction of its volume is submerged?
Compare the submerged volume of an iceberg in fresh water (ρ_l=1.0 g/cm³) versus in sea water (ρ_l=1.026 g/cm³).

options.label: A
options.text: It submerges more in fresh water (larger v).

options.label: B
options.text: It submerges less in sea water (smaller v).

options.label: C
options.text: Submerged volume is the same in both.

options.label: D
options.text: It floats completely out in sea water.

questions.key_concept: Effect of liquid density on submerged volume

questions.question_text: Why does a ship loaded with cargo submerge more in water?

options.label: A
options.text: Its average density increases, so to balance the increased weight, it needs to displace more water (increase submerged volume).

options.label: B
options.text: The cargo makes the ship less dense.

options.label: C
options.text: The shape of the ship changes.

options.label: D
options.text: Water becomes denser.

questions.key_concept: Effect of loading on submerged volume
